page.title: 07LANDSCAPE IN CRUDEN BAY.
page.content: The oldest part of Slains Castle was built in the 16th Century. It was on the cliff top for defence. The owners were the Earls of Erroll, the Lord High Constables of Scotland. The castle grew bigger and bigger as the years passed because parts were added on to it by successive Earls. The roof was taken off in 1927. All the furniture had been taken out and much of it sold by 1923. The Castle is now in ruins but people come to visit it from all over the World. Its main claim to fame is that it inspired Bram Stoker to write the Dracula story. He was staying at the Kilmarnock Arms Hotel at the time. The oldest part of the village is made up of granite built houses, while the two newer Estates consist of wooden Norwegian type houses and other built of 'breeze blocks'.
